Having briefly repented the afflictive hindrances, I will now next repent the karmic hindrances.

Karma can adorn the worldly realms everywhere, therefore contemplating seeking to leave the world and attain liberation. The reason the fruits and retributions of the six paths are various and different, and the forms and species are distinct, is because they are all created by the power of karma.
Among the ten powers of the Buddha, the power of karma is extremely profound. Ordinary people often give rise to doubts in this regard.
Why is this so?
It is because in the present world, those who do good encounter difficulties, while those who do evil find everything going their way.
They say that in the world, good and evil are not distinguished.
Those who think like this all fail to deeply understand the principle of karma.
Why is this so?
The sutras say that there are three kinds of karma.
What are the three?
First, karma with present retribution;
second, karma with retribution in the next life;

third, karma with retribution in future lives.ğŸ”½Karma with present retribution means creating good or evil karma in the present life and receiving retribution in this body.ğŸ”½Karma with retribution in the next life means creating good or evil karma in this life and receiving retribution in the next life.
Karma with retribution in future lives means creating good or evil karma in the past, countless lives, or in this life, and receiving retribution in the present, future, or countless lives.

Those who previously engaged in evil but now see goodness, this is because the wholesome karma of the ripening of the present life and the ripening of the later life in past lives has matured, so they have this pleasant result in the present life. How is it related to creating various evil karma in the present life and receiving a good retribution?

Those who engage in wholesome conduct but now see suffering, this is because the unwholesome karma of the ripening of the present life and the ripening of the later life in past lives has matured, so the wholesome roots in the present life are weak and cannot be dispelled, and therefore they receive this painful retribution. How is it related to creating wholesome karma in the present life and inviting an evil retribution?
How do we know this to be so?
We currently see in the world that those who do good are praised by others and respected by people, so we know that in the future they will definitely receive pleasant results.

Since there was such unwholesome karma in the past, the Buddhas and Bodhisattvas teach us to be close to good friends and to repent together. A good and virtuous friend is of great benefit in attaining the Way.
For this reason, disciples, we now take refuge in the Buddha with utmost sincerity.

Why is it called the Molten Copper Pouring into the Mouth Hell?

The hell is twenty-four yojanas long and wide, surrounded by iron walls and covered with an iron net, with flames blazing everywhere, smoke and fire raging together without rest, and iron spikes spread all over the ground.

The ground is on fire, reaching up to the net above, penetrating from above to below and from below to above, with smoke and flames raging, burning and cooking the sinners. In the hell there is a large iron pond from which molten iron flows out, with smoke and flames raging, and molten iron pouring down like flowing water into the sinners' mouths.
At that time, in the southern gate there were fifty monks, with fire coming out of their mouths and eyes, crying out:
Why do we now suffer such pain?
They rolled on the ground and refused to get up.

The horse-headed rakshasa held a three-pronged iron trident in his hand, kicked the ground with it, and the prongs of the trident all emitted flames that burned the sinners' hearts, and they died in an instant and came back to life in an instant.
There were also iron hooks that came to hook their tongues, iron clubs that came to beat their heads, and flying knives that came to peel their flesh.

The horse-headed rakshasa led the monks into the river of flowing fire. The horse-headed rakshasa took an iron scoop and scooped up iron fireballs, pouring them into their mouths. The iron pellets entered through the mouth and exited through the back, with smoke and flames burning from the mouth, eyes, and six orifices, with the iron pellets continuing without rest.
Baodala asked the horse-headed rakshasa:
What crimes did these sinful monks commit to suffer such torment?
The rakshasa replied:

These monks did not uphold the Buddha's precepts, did not fear the retribution of suffering, greedily sought profit and fame, and had no sense of shame. They committed the four grave offenses and claimed to uphold pure conduct.

Having received people's offerings of faith, they greedily seek food and drink. They say they can digest the heavy offerings of laypeople, which are very difficult to digest, but they do not know the Three Jewels, the Four Truths, or the causes and conditions, just like the great ocean that does not know satisfaction.
For these causes and conditions, they fall into the suffering of the hells for thousands of myriads of kalpas. When reborn as humans, they are dumb and cannot speak.
Bodhisattva Baodai heard this and wept sorrowfully, saying:
How is it that those who have attained liberation now experience such suffering?
How is it that after crossing the ocean, they return to the great ocean?
How is it that after being greatly wealthy and noble, they again become poor and destitute?
How is it that after receiving the pure precepts, they violate them without fear,
and return to falling into the path of wrong views?
